headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And next is Christine Farkas with Bank of America.
componenttext: And next is Christine Farkas with Bank of America.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm hoping to dive into North America a little bit. Correct me if I'm wrong, but this is the first quarter I've seen were sparkling outperformed still beverages. And I'm wondering if mix had something to do with your margin improvement or if there were ot
componenttext: I'm hoping to dive into North America a little bit. Correct me if I'm wrong, but this is the first quarter I've seen were sparkling outperformed still beverages. And I'm wondering if mix had something to do with your margin improvement or if there were other factors. And speaking to the still beverages, certainly cycling a strong POWERade comp, but can you talk about the other non-water still beverages and the performance in the quarter?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Christine. You're right in pointing that out and I think that we’re also pleased with that. And that is testimony to not only -- again, work that's been done in this past quarter, but the work that we've been doing in our brands and strengthenin
componenttext: Thanks, Christine. You're right in pointing that out and I think that we’re also pleased with that. And that is testimony to not only -- again, work that's been done in this past quarter, but the work that we've been doing in our brands and strengthening our brands, particularly sparkling brands. The investments that are going into the sparkling brand for the last year and a half, and again our brand metrics for our sparkling brands are healthier than we've seen them in many, many years. Coca-Cola Zero, again, had a very, very strong quarter in the United States. And again, still tremendous room to grow in the United States going forward. So I think packaging is working. Our $0.99 single-serve is working. The contourization as is now in more than 50% of the country and getting tremendous distribution coverage is working very well. So all those programs that we've put into place last year and even at the end of 2008 are beginning to bear fruit. So that's why we see an improving landscape in the Sparkling category in the United States and our brands in that category. As far as still beverages are concerned, I think Sports -- POWERade, again, cycling a very strong prior year quarter at more than double-digits growth from last year, grew this year, which was very pleasing. We, I think, gained volume and value share in the juice and juice drinks category as expansion of Simply Orange in both Packaging and Cold channel lead to another quarter of double-digit growth, which was very pleasing. And again, we also made the strategic decision to exit the lower margin Retail Spring Water segment of the Water category. And accordingly, we've eliminated the Retail Spring Customer Brand Water volume from our reported results for 2010, as well as 2009. And I can reiterate that this change does not impact either the Company’s or our North America's reported volumes results this quarter. And again, I think vitaminwater. We're very excited with the changes we've made: new product innovation of vitaminwater zero, as well as packaging, as well as the advertising. And we expect to deliver stronger results through the balance of the year, with again, that strong brand. Our energy brand, NOS, continued to grow very effectively in the quarter, as well as also our Smartwater. So I think overall, those are the sort of important point that I'd like to make about our North American business that you asked, Christine.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering if on the Philippines the momentum has continued and you saw positive growth in the first quarter?
componenttext: I'm just wondering if on the Philippines the momentum has continued and you saw positive growth in the first quarter?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I'd say that I think all the hard work that’s -- our PAG [ph] group is doing in the Philippines is beginning to pay dividends. And I'm pleased, although not ecstatic, because I think there's still room for improvement.
componenttext: I'd say that I think all the hard work that’s -- our PAG [ph] group is doing in the Philippines is beginning to pay dividends. And I'm pleased, although not ecstatic, because I think there's still room for improvement.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And next is Judy Hong from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And next is Judy Hong from Goldman Sachs.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you look at -- we have certainly had good results in our value share in North America in sparkling. And I'm pleased with that. I think the category -- it's too early to say whether the category is beginning to improve. All I can tell you
componenttext: Well, I think if you look at -- we have certainly had good results in our value share in North America in sparkling. And I'm pleased with that. I think the category -- it's too early to say whether the category is beginning to improve. All I can tell you is that our Foodservice business, our Fountain business, which is a great litmus test for consumer sentiment, we saw some improvement in the latter half of the quarter. But again, as I referenced to Christine's question, it's really important to understand that these packaging changes and also our Open Happiness campaign, our branding, our connection with the Olympics property in the quarter, all of that plays very well into our brands. And again, our brands are getting healthier. Our packaging, as I said, is working; 50% coverage in the entire United States on our contourization for two liter. The pricing of two liter, again, versus the single-serves are in a much better place than it was back 18 months ago. All of that is beginning to show -- the logic of all of that is beginning to pay dividends.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, U.K. was slightly down. But I think really important to understand is about Germany -- what is happening in Germany has got nothing to do with this past quarter or this past year. This is -- Germany was not a market that needed to be fixed. Germany,
componenttext: Yes, U.K. was slightly down. But I think really important to understand is about Germany -- what is happening in Germany has got nothing to do with this past quarter or this past year. This is -- Germany was not a market that needed to be fixed. Germany, as you know, it took us years to try and to ensure that we could put the right structure in Germany. We closed the deal finally and then in 2006. And we've been busy putting ourselves to work to get Germany right. So it's really important to understand that this is not a program that suddenly came into being last quarter or last year. We've been working on getting Germany right. Is Germany right? I'd say probably more than certainly 50% right. And I am confident that looking into the future, Germany is going to start yielding some good dividends as we move towards franchising Germany in the period that we've announced. But think of it along the same lines as what we're doing in the United States. These are long-term programs that we commit ourselves to fixing major markets. Germany was a big one, internationally. And now we see that it's on the way to repair and it's going to be -- it's finding the right home.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from John Faucher with JPMorgan Chase.
componenttext: And the next question comes from John Faucher with JPMorgan Chase.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Quick question on the North American volume. I apologize for following up on this. Muhtar, you said it didn't impact -- the loss of the Spring Water business didn't affect the volume numbers. Is that because you excluded it from both years? Or was that be
componenttext: Quick question on the North American volume. I apologize for following up on this. Muhtar, you said it didn't impact -- the loss of the Spring Water business didn't affect the volume numbers. Is that because you excluded it from both years? Or was that because it was so small that it was just –- it was less than 1%?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Oh, because we excluded it from both years, but Gary can give you more details on that. But we –- the answer is we excluded it from both years.
componenttext: Oh, because we excluded it from both years, but Gary can give you more details on that. But we –- the answer is we excluded it from both years.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, we excluded it from both years, but it's very small and did not impact the volume growth rate of North America at all. It’s less -- on a full year basis, it's less than 1% of North America.
componenttext: Yes, John, we excluded it from both years, but it's very small and did not impact the volume growth rate of North America at all. It’s less -- on a full year basis, it's less than 1% of North America.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then going back to the Japan question that Mark had. And I guess as we look at the price mix in the Pacific, how much of the price mix issue -- you talk about the strength of CSDs. How much of the price mix issue in Asia is related to low
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then going back to the Japan question that Mark had. And I guess as we look at the price mix in the Pacific, how much of the price mix issue -- you talk about the strength of CSDs. How much of the price mix issue in Asia is related to lower, non-carb volumes, this strategic push into CSDs and the channel mix that entails? And I guess is that one of the mix problems that we should expect to improve over the next couple of quarters, or is that one going to take a little bit longer?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, I think it's more related also to the channel in Japan. And the channel was under tremendous pressure this time last year and remained under tremendous pressure for all of 2009. And as I mentioned in an earlier comment, we see some beginnings o
componenttext: Yes, John, I think it's more related also to the channel in Japan. And the channel was under tremendous pressure this time last year and remained under tremendous pressure for all of 2009. And as I mentioned in an earlier comment, we see some beginnings of some light there in the very critical Vending channel. And I think that is much more critical to the revenue and to the NSR than the different product categories. Also CBS I think, we're beginning to see some really good developments -- positive developments in the CBS channel as well. But I think Vending, which is a really critical channel is beginning to show some lights -- improved lights.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then one follow-up there which is when you look at that impact, whether it’s the channel piece or the mix from non-carbs into CSDs, how much of the global mix decline do you think that is? Is that a small piece or is that a pretty sizable piece, j
componenttext: Okay. Then one follow-up there which is when you look at that impact, whether it’s the channel piece or the mix from non-carbs into CSDs, how much of the global mix decline do you think that is? Is that a small piece or is that a pretty sizable piece, just for the Japan portions?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say on a global basis, it's that not that sizable.
componenttext: I would say on a global basis, it's that not that sizable.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Mark Swartzberg with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Mark Swartzberg with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Muhtar, on Mexico. Could you give us a more color on the performance in the quarter, including that sequential improvement? And then share with us more on your outlook for Mexico?
componenttext: Muhtar, on Mexico. Could you give us a more color on the performance in the quarter, including that sequential improvement? And then share with us more on your outlook for Mexico?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: I think first -- again, the portfolio is working very well in the company. I just want to reiterate, as I get into the Mexico details because in our quarter in where Mexico was down and a quarter where China grew mid-single digits, we achieved a strong, I
componenttext: I think first -- again, the portfolio is working very well in the company. I just want to reiterate, as I get into the Mexico details because in our quarter in where Mexico was down and a quarter where China grew mid-single digits, we achieved a strong, I may add, organic 3% plus growth in our global volume. And I think that's a testimony to how well we're doing all across the world and our brands are doing all across our world. And our investment programs are paying off all across the world. So that's point number one. Number two, on Mexico, very, very unseasonable weather. And I think essentially we have seen improved results, positive rates of growth in the latter part of the quarter. And I think that leads me to believe that we will put back to trends at Mexico.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And next is Lauren Torres with HSBC.
componenttext: And next is Lauren Torres with HSBC.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Lauren, I think I see it as this way. Russia always goes deeper and comes back quicker and with more rigor. And so therefore, that's what's we're going to see, I believe, in Russia. It'll come back. And you'll see a more market return of the Russian consu
componenttext: Lauren, I think I see it as this way. Russia always goes deeper and comes back quicker and with more rigor. And so therefore, that's what's we're going to see, I believe, in Russia. It'll come back. And you'll see a more market return of the Russian consumers back to their normal habits, I believe, in the coming year or so. And I think that the return to normalcy in Eastern Europe is going to take a little longer, although Eastern Europe didn't go down as far as Russia. So I think those are the comments. I think Russia already after, as you said, a very difficult consumer environment in 2009, where we saw double-digit declines for the whole CPG sector, is beginning to show again positive developments, where we're almost even in the quarter in Russia, minus one. And we grew -- importantly grew Trademark Coca-Cola double-digits in Russia, which, as I said, was pleasing for me. So as we go into the summer, and Russia, again, is a very seasonal-dependent market, I believe that we will see sequential improvement in both the sentiments of the consumer in Russia, the spending of the consumer in Russia and also our business.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think I can't give you any more details, but I can tell you the following that certainly Eastern Europe, Southeast Europe was not as strong as some of those markets that we referenced. Spain continues to be challenged, for example.
componenttext: Well, I think I can't give you any more details, but I can tell you the following that certainly Eastern Europe, Southeast Europe was not as strong as some of those markets that we referenced. Spain continues to be challenged, for example.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010

componenttext: Next is Caroline Levy with CLSA.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Just want to dig into, number one, market share in North America. Just to make sure, it seems that you did lose overall market share in North America, even though you gained in stills. And I'm just wondering why you think that might have happened?
componenttext: Just want to dig into, number one, market share in North America. Just to make sure, it seems that you did lose overall market share in North America, even though you gained in stills. And I'm just wondering why you think that might have happened?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Caroline, I think on -- as far as North America is concerned, we have essentially in terms of our value share in the quarter in sparkling, we lost some little bit of value share in the full quarter as we looked into our volume share in North America
componenttext: Well, Caroline, I think on -- as far as North America is concerned, we have essentially in terms of our value share in the quarter in sparkling, we lost some little bit of value share in the full quarter as we looked into our volume share in North America. Again, we had slight losses in sparkling and also in still. And I think that is, again, a result of our discipline in pricing in the United States. And what we saw is a bigger loss of share in the beginning of the quarter and some of that share was coming back in the latter part -- share gains were coming back in the latter part of the quarter to result in slightly down share in both volume and value and in both still and sparkling.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And do you expect to reverse that? And are you saying it's a function of a widening price cap versus the competition?
componenttext: And do you expect to reverse that? And are you saying it's a function of a widening price cap versus the competition?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: No. I think as I said it was the difference between the first half of the quarter and the second half. A volume share decline was mainly due to aggressive –- very aggressive competitive pricing in the beginning of the quarter, bundling and so forth, as
componenttext: No. I think as I said it was the difference between the first half of the quarter and the second half. A volume share decline was mainly due to aggressive –- very aggressive competitive pricing in the beginning of the quarter, bundling and so forth, as well as pricing. But I think CCNA and CCE continue to focus on building consumer and customer value through strong brands. And we see tremendous value from being disciplined in our future pricing between our future consumption and our immediate consumption channels. And I think therefore, that we anticipate also that the industry will return definitely to rational pricing through the balance of the year. And we've seen some of that also in the latter –- certainly in the latter half of the quarter.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: And then in China, your comps actually get much harder -- your comparisons as you move through the year. So do you think this is perhaps a year where we should not expect double-digit volume growth in China?
componenttext: And then in China, your comps actually get much harder -- your comparisons as you move through the year. So do you think this is perhaps a year where we should not expect double-digit volume growth in China?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first Caroline, I think China continues to remain the most important growth market for the company. And I think through the end of 2009, as you saw, we held double digits in China. It's been 26 consecutive quarters since 2003 until the end of 2009.
componenttext: Well, first Caroline, I think China continues to remain the most important growth market for the company. And I think through the end of 2009, as you saw, we held double digits in China. It's been 26 consecutive quarters since 2003 until the end of 2009. And during that time, '03 to '09, our base grew three-folds, almost to 1.8 billion cases or over 400 billion servings per annum. And having said that, I think China remains -- we all know that China remains a complex, rapidly changing market. But I can reiterate one thing: our brands, our investment, our innovation platforms remain very healthy. And I would state that we would be disappointed, if we would not continue to achieve double-digit growth on an annual basis in China going forward. And if you view our business in China over the past six months, our volume grew –- our volume averaged a 16% growth over the last six months, very consistent with same prior year period. And this is very similar to what you would've seen also, if you compared quarter four of '08 versus quarter one of '09.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010

componenttext: I just have a question for Gary. Currency looks like it added $0.05. So it would've been $0.75 without the currency benefit. Is that right?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's about right, Carol.
componenttext: Yes, that's about right, Carol.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-20-2010
